newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine peso defensive on renewed speculation.
newsitem.headline: Philippine peso defensive on renewed speculation.

text.p: The Philippine peso was on the defensive on Friday as speculation was rekindled by banks betting on a downtrend in rates and the tension that may come from the political instability in Jakarta, traders said.
The peso closed unchanged at 26.375 pesos, the rate at which the Central Bank had been selling dollars to curb the peso's weakness.
Traders estimate the Central Bank sold $167 million to $169 million, the bulk of which was unloaded in the afternoon.
Trading volume swelled to $327 million from $202 million.
"Right now, there are no inflows because of the riots in Indonesia," a foreign bank dealer said.
"Only until the situation stabilises in Asia will we see inflows returning," a dealer said.
Last week, regional markets were in turmoil because of the Thai baht's problems.
Traders said the Central Bank might not lower its key rate further as earlier anticipated by other banks.
On Thursday, the Central Bank cut its overnight borrowing rate by two percentage points to 18 percent. This came a week after the Central Bank raised its rate several times.
